query_refined: Define explain the notion of machine-generated text threats discussed in the corpus., describe its theoretical foundations, and explain how definitions evolved historically across publications.
prompt_final_to_llm:
You are a domain expert in Artificial Intelligence. Provide a precise definition, clarify theoretical foundations, and explain how interpretations evolved across time and publications. Use event years ONLY if explicitly stated in the snippets. Use numeric IEEE-style citations [1], [2], etc., for statements supported by the provided snippets. Each number corresponds to one unique PDF listed below. Multiple snippets originating from the same PDF share the same number. Never assign multiple citation numbers to the same source.

**Your final answer MUST end with a separate section titled 'References'.**
This section MUST list all unique PDFs exactly once, in the following strict format:
[n] FILENAME.pdf (YEAR)

Do not fabricate author names, journals, or article titles — only use the given filename and metadata year.

Temporal Attribution Rules:
1. You may ONLY use event years that appear explicitly in the snippet text.
2. If the snippet text explicitly contains a year (e.g., 'In the 1950s', 'In 1976'), treat that as the factual historical reference.
3. If a snippet DOES NOT contain an explicit event year, you MUST NOT guess, infer, approximate, or estimate any year.
   Instead, write exactly: '(event year not stated; described in YEAR PDF [n])'.
4. The metadata publication year indicates only when the PDF was published, not when the events occurred.
5. Never replace or override an explicit event year with a metadata year.
6. Never deduce approximate historical periods from textual content (e.g., never infer '1990s' unless explicitly stated).

Output Structuring Guidelines:
- For every key historical or conceptual point:
  • If an explicit event year exists in the snippet → include it.
  • If no explicit event year exists → write '(event year not stated; described in YEAR PDF [n])'.
- Recommended dual-year structure:
  • (1950s; described in 2025 PDF [7]) The Turing Test was proposed as a benchmark.
This dual timestamping ensures full temporal grounding without hallucination.

IMPORTANT:
**Your output MUST end with a final section titled 'References'.**
This section must list all unique PDFs exactly once in IEEE numeric format.

Refined query:

. To understand the risks that motivate research on detection of machine generated text, we draw from existing literature to present a series of threat models incorporating natural language generation. Threat modeling reflects the process of thinking like an attacker, identifying vulnerabilities to systems by identifying potential attackers, their capabilities, and objectives. . The goal of threat modeling is to improve the security of systems by considering the greatest threats to systems and t

[1] 2210.07321v4.pdf (2023)
. MACHINE GENERATED TEXT Before reviewing threat models and detection methodologies for machine generated text, it is helpful to briefly provide a formal definition of machine generated text, and a condensed overview of natural language generation (NLG) models. We recommend further reading of dedicated surveys on natural language generation for greater insight into the wide breadth of NLG models and applications.

[1] 2210.07321v4.pdf (2023)
The result of our threat modeling process is a series of threat models that describe scenarios where machine generated text may be abused, the likely methodology of attackers, and existing research related to each threat. To date, there has yet to be any survey of machine generated text detection with a focus on the risks presented by machine generated text. . Consideration of threat models is vital to set the groundwork for trustworthy development of NLG technology, encourage early development

[1] 2210.07321v4.pdf (2023)
. DETECTION OF MACHINE GENERATED TEXT Analysis of threat models indicates that the detection of machine generated text, when utilized correctly, is a valuable tool for reducing the harms of NLG model abuse.

[1] 2210.07321v4.pdf (2023)
. To summarize, the major contributions of this work are as follows: • The most complete survey of machine generated text detection to date, including previously omitted feature-based work and findings from recent contemporary research.. • The first detailed review of the threat models enabled by machine generated text, at a critical juncture where NLG models and tools are rapidly improving and proliferating. . • . A meaningful exploration of both topics through the lens of Trustworthy AI (TAI),

In the majority of cases, the production of new text is not the primary goal of a text adversarial attack, and text adversarial attacks and threat models are already covered by surveys in adversarial attack literature. We will nevertheless discuss the role machine generated text plays in adversarial contexts in Section 3, as well as adversarial robustness of detection models in Section 5.
